content.description: A great Tongue River standard limbstone trad crack that is a great long route to hit when the other side of the canyon is either too busy by the local "hikers" or too hot.
content.protection:
Well Armed Militia climbs a mix of sizes but pinches down to small tips when the cracks swings left. Bring extra smalls and save a small nut for the top just bellow the anchors.

Standard rack with doubles in small cams and stoppers
content.location: The approach trail for the prow area brings you almost directly to the base of this crack. This is the right under belly crack route and does not have bolts at the base.

content.description: Climb the somewhat crumbly bottom protected with bolts until merging into the crack. The bottom crack section leads to some fun cranking when things cut left. Place a good piece and traverse under the roof bulge getting another piece in before pulling through. Clip one more bolt and head for the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a single set of cams and stoppers up to 3
content.location: Once at the base the prow amphitheater, S.W.A.W. crack is one crack to the left of Well Armed Militia (The first main crack when the trail meets the wall) and the first three bolts can be seen leading into the crack.

content.description: A monster neo tongue classic! The Prow starts atop a 15 foot 5.4 ledge and then up a slightly less than vertical face through a number of pockets and bulges, topped with a slight traverse and then up through a pocketed roof section. From there it turns into a tiring lay back/stemming endurance tester to a small ledge. The anchors are one hard roof move away and only honesty can keep you from not grabbing the anchors when pulling the last moves. These anchors are set with just enough room to lower to the first bolt and then down climb the final 15 feet or just bring a 70m and dont worry. The Prow route is a great endurance test piece. Possible the best route in the canyon!
content.location: The right most route found in the amphitheater

content.description: The first sport route put up on the wall and was aided on hooks and removable bolts by H. Lynn to grant access to the cleaning and bolting of The Prow. Access route climbs a somewhat dirty, less than vertical face up the center of the prow areas amphitheater.
content.location: The left most bolted route currently on the wall, accessed by climbing/stepping atop a boulder to gain access to the beginning of the climb
